results.title: Batman
results.creator_credit: Guber-Peters Company, Warner Bros Pictures, Jon Peters, Peter Guber and Tim Burton
results.brief_description: Based on the comic book character created by Bob Kane, this “Batman” reflects the darkness of the original syndication and in no way resembles the 1960’s successful television series of the same name. Michael Keaton is Batman and Jack Nicholson portrays “The Joker”, his arch enemy. The sets are dark, gigantic and forbidding and the finale is set amongst a cathedral backdrop reminiscent of the set of “The Hunchback of Notre Dame”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Guber-Peters Company, Warner Bros Pictures, Jon Peters, Peter Guber and Tim Burton

results.title: Les Yeux Fermes = the Eyes Closed
results.brief_description:
Ivan returns from touring with a theatre company. During the tour one of Ivan’s friend died. Back in Paris, Ivan experiences vision toubles and buys a pair of black glasses. From then on, he starts pretending to be a blind man. His girlfriend Xenie witnesses helplessly the slow march towards madness of a ‘blind’ man whose only markers are noises and memories..

Credits: Director, Joel Santoni ; writer, Jeanne Bronner, Joel Santoni, Claude Breuer ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Terry Riley.
Cast: Gerard Desarthe, Lorraine Rainer, Jean Carmet, Marcel Dalio, Lucien Raimbourg.

results.title: Tomatoes for Troops
results.creator_credit: Bob Harper, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an example of propaganda for the war effort, encouraging farmers to grow tomatoes for the armed forces during the Second World War. The film includes footage of soldiers on the Kokoda Trail, and outlines the importance of vegetables for the armed forces in combat overseas.

The film takes the viewer through the stages of tomato production on a mass scale, showing the process of collecting, disinfecting and washing seeds; cultivating and fertilising the soil; planting the seedlings and maximising growth. The film then outlines common diseases and pests that threaten the healthy growth of tomato plants, such as spotted wilt, tomato moths and weevils, along with preventative measures to mitigate these risks.

Finally, the film shows the industrial-scale quality assessment and canning of tomatoes in a factory. The final product, shown in the hands of an active soldier, is a can of SPC peeled tomatoes.

results.title: Project the right image
results.brief_description:
English production, NOT made by the Department of Agriculture.

Details hot to and how not to project a 16mm film using a social church gathering as the backdrop. Stars a bumbling projectionist and a priest who first do everything the wrong way and then do everything the correct way.

Comical (in a daggy way) throughout with good use of slapstick humour. Also contains an amusing, very dry voiceover.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.brief_description:
‘Harry She’llberight’ is a lazy farmer, stuck in the ‘old ways’ of chemical spraying. He provides a ‘worst case scenario’ of chemical spray use. A representative of the Vistorian Department of Agriculture assists Harry in modern spraying techniques, equipment and safety. Along the way we are introduced to different spray epuipment and how it operates away from Harry’s farm.

Harry is a comical character and he eventually gets his act together as the film progresses.

Opening contains nice shots of people picking lettuce and scens inside of a vegetable market.

Good cartoon-like illustrations about chemical spraying safety.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.

results.title: Lichtspiel Schwarz-Weiss-Grau
results.brief_description:
In 1930, after eight years of research and experimentation, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy created the Light Space Modulator, a kinetic sculpture of rotating glass, spirals and perforated metal sheets illuminated by 140 different light sources. In this same year, he produced the film Lightplay Black White Grey, a dynamic cinematic abstraction of the light and movement generated by the Light Space Modulator. The play of light in the film, as in the original sculpture, enabled Moholy-Nagy to create an altogether new experience for the viewer, asserting his own proposition that,
“Because light is a spatial-temporal problem, the mere accentuation of the question of light brings us into the field of a new spatial awareness that cannot yet be fully analysed. We can, however, find a word to describe it: floating.”
Moholy-Nagy also saw his Light Space Modulator as an extension of the ideas underpinning cinema - magnified light projected on a surface in dynamic configurations. As such, Lightplay Black White Grey, his cinematic mediation of these spatial and light concerns is a vital work in his artistic practise. The film begins as a series of abstract images of geometric shapes and shadows formed by the kinetic movement of the Light Space Modulator. The circular movements of the sculpture and camera in combination provide a pendulous, hypnotic effect that is both a document of the sculpture and an elegant visual dance of shape-shifting forms and transformed light. The rhythmic combinations of stasis and dynamism across altered variations of screen space and superimpositions of motion and form makes for a vertiginous visual experience.
Although it cannot replicate the immersive experience of the light sculpture, the film creates a viewing space in which the audience is visually disoriented by Moholy-Nagy’s spatial dislocations. As the artist anticipated, this creates a sensation of detachment, of ‘floating’, amid a dynamic vision of light’s relationship to spatial understanding.

results.title: The Poetry Cup
results.creator_credit: Terrence Doran, Ken Smeaton and Peter Lane
results.brief_description: The inaugural Poetry Cup was filmed in September at the Rochester Castle Hotel, Fitzroy as part of the 1989 Spoleto Fringe Festival. Just as the comedy resurgence began in the small cafes and clubs before moving to a wider television audience so then the poets. These people are performers with an emphasis on entertainment. No quiet reads here, but full blooded performance poetry. Their skills have been honed amid beer, smoke, pool players and football, in the back rooms of inner city hotels such as the Provincial, the Rochester, the Leicester Arms and cafes, prisons, schools and the streets.
